definition.name: Giant Foundling
definition.description:
Though you aren’t a Giant, you grew up among giants. Maybe you were an orphan taken in by a sympathetic family of stone giants who raised you as one of their own. Or perhaps you lived in a lost prehistoric pocket of the world, surrounded by giants and fearsome behemoths or hulking dinosaurs.

Something about your environment—perhaps the food or water that sustained you, elemental magic inherent in the site of your home, or some verdant blessing of growth placed on you—caused you to grow to a remarkable size for your kind. With the aid of this magic, you have learned how to embody the might of giants. You are used to moving through a world much bigger than you, and that is reflected in your skills, attitude, and perspective on life.

Skill Proficiencies: Intimidation, Survival

Languages: Giant and one other language of your choice

Equipment: A backpack, a set of traveler’s clothes, a small stone or sprig that reminds you of home, and a pouch containing 10 gp

Origin Stories

How you came to live among colossal creatures is up to you to determine, but the Foundling Origin table suggests a variety of possibilities.

Foundling Origin
d6 Origin
1 You were found as a baby by a family of nomadic giants who raised you as one of their own.
2 A family of stone giants rescued you when you fell into a mountain chasm, and you have lived with them underground ever since.
3 You were lost or abandoned as a child in a jungle that teemed with ravenous dinosaurs. There, you found an equally lost frost giant; together, you survived.
4 Your farm was crushed and your family killed in a battle between warring groups of giants. Racked with guilt over the destruction, a sympathetic giant soldier promised to care for you.
5 After you had a series of strange dreams as a child, your superstitious parents sent you to study with a powerful but aloof storm giant oracle.
6 While playing hide-and-seek with your friends, you stumbled into the castle of a cloud giant, who immediately adopted you.
Feature: Strike of the Giants

You gain the Strike of the Giants feat.

Something about your environment—perhaps the food or water that sustained you, elemental magic inherent in the site of your home, or some verdant blessing of growth placed on you—caused you to grow to a remarkable size for your kind. With the aid of this magic, you have learned how to embody the might of giants. You are used to moving through a world much bigger than you, and that is reflected in your skills, attitude, and perspective on life.

definition.suggestedCharacteristicsDescription: The Giant Foundling Personality Traits table suggests a variety of traits you might adopt for your character.
definition.spellsPostDescription:
Building a Giant Foundling Character

Your life among giants has given you a unique perspective. Though you are unusually large for your kind, you’re no larger than a giant child, so you might be very mindful of your size.

personalityTraits.description: What I lack in stature compared to giants, I make up for with sheer spite.
I insist on being taken seriously as a full-grown adult. Nobody talks down to me!
Crowded spaces make me uncomfortable. I’d much rather be in an open field than a bustling tavern.
I embrace my shorter stature. It helps me stay unnoticed—and underestimated.
Every avalanche begins as a single pebble.
The world always feels too big, and I’m afraid I’ll never find my place in it.

race.description:
Distantly related to giants and infused with the supernatural essence of their ancestors’ mountainous home.

Goliath Traits
Little Giant, Mountain Born, Stone’s Endurance

definition.name: Ability Score Increases
definition.description: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1, or increase three different scores by 1. Follow this rule regardless of the method you use to determine the scores, such as rolling or point buy. The “Quick Build” section for your character’s class offers suggestions on which scores to increase. You can follow those suggestions or ignore them, but you can’t raise any of your scores above 20.
definition.snippet: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1, or increase three different scores by 1.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for the character. The Player’s Handbook offers a list of languages to choose from. The DM is free to modify that list for a campaign.
definition.snippet: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for the character.

definition.name: Creature Type
definition.description: You are a Humanoid.
definition.snippet: You are a Humanoid.

definition.name: Size
definition.description: You are Medium.
definition.snippet: You are Medium.

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your walking speed is 30 feet.
definition.snippet: Your walking speed is 30 ft.

definition.name: Little Giant
definition.description: You have proficiency in the Athletics skill, and you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.
definition.snippet: You’re proficient with Athletics and you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

definition.name: Mountain Born
definition.description: You have resistance to cold damage. You also naturally acclimate to high altitudes, even if you’ve never been to one. This includes elevations above 20,000 feet.
definition.snippet: You have resistance to cold damage and naturally acclimate to high altitudes even if you’ve never been to one. This includes elevations above 20,000 ft.

definition.name: Stone’s Endurance
definition.description:
You can supernaturally draw on unyielding stone to shrug off harm. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to roll a d12. Add your Constitution modifier to the number rolled and reduce the damage by that total.

You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
definition.snippet: When you take damage, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage taken by 1d12{{modifier:con#signed}}. You can use this trait {{proficiency#unsigned}} times per long rest.

notes.allies: Before this adventure started, Muninn had just himself.  For a short time he partnered with a Dwarf, earning money from mercenary work for local towns.  But he didn't speak Dwarvish, and the Dwarf didn't speak Common.  Never got his name.
notes.organizations: After being on this Cult of the Dragon mission, Muninn is currently a member of the Order of the Gauntlet.  And he is attached to The Harpers.  He's had minor associations with the Lord's Alliance, Zhentarim, Thieves Guild, and the Emerald Enclave.
notes.backstory:
We were a tribe of two, my brother and I. Twin boys, born of an outcast Mother. Why she was cast out, we never knew. But she was not like any other Goliaths we've met. She was kind and caring, had a love for nature and all life. For true, it seemed the flowers bloomed with more glory when she was around. A peaceful Goliath is not heard of. Which made being our mother all the harder on her. She could not raise the competitive nature out of us. We had to be better than the other. And it was always Huginn that came out on top. 

We never knew our mother's tribe.  She wouldn't tell us.  Just that she could not travel the mountains anymore, as the tribes would not take kindly to her presence.  She must have been chased out while pregnant.  Giving birth in the woods just south of the mountain range.  Near the River Surbrin of the Cold Wood.  She was able to hide herself, and us as babes, in these woods.  Raised us to early adulthood.  We moved through the forests across the base of the mountains.  Always telling us that we needed to be by each other side, AT ALL TIMES!  Mother was very adamant about this.  We didn't have anyone else to be around, and as kids it was great.  She never spoke of our father.  But the stories she told us over our campfires seemed to always be about one great man.  Huginn and I liked to imagine this great man was our father.  

He wielded great power and magic.  The magics made us think he was not a Goliath, our people tended to not use the stuff.  She described him as a great leader.  Brought his people amazing gifts and powers.  Built them an incredible home outside of the mortal plane with all they would ever need.  Their home was far from here, and not reachable by most.  But he would venture into our world and walk amongst it's people.  It amused him to no end to hear the tales of mortals.  He had two Ravens with him at most times.  But they would fly through the worlds, gathering information for him.  Mother must have liked these stories a lot, as she named us after these Ravens.  Huginn and Muninn they were called, meaning Thought and Memory.  The stories were always so good to hear.  Sometimes he fought giants of fire and ice.  Sometimes he fought Gods.  Always victorious, but not always without cost.  His son, Tyr, lost a hand once to his step grandchild.  That was a wolf apparently.  Their family is weird.  I'm glad ours is small.  No one here biting my hand off.  Huginn's mouth isn't big enough anyway.

My brother, he was a great man. Was destined to be at least. We were both reflections and shadows of each other. He was motivated, I was lazy. He thoughtful, I selfish. He was capable, and I was almost...feeble. For a Goliath at least, that's how it felt. No matter what I did, I just could not beat him. Not in any way. Neither of us were big thinkers, but he could twist my brain into knots. It was all in good fun as Huginn never had ill intent. He never hurt me for fun. I earned it. For I would try to find short cuts to everything. 

I guess he came out first.  Always had the best of everything.  Stronger, smarter, and apparently more attractive.  I always thought we looked the same.  But as time went on, I got fatter and more scars.  Because I was lazy and got hit more.  Guess they made me ugly.  For the only woman, not our mother, that every came into our loves seemed to like him more.  Kelga, that was her name.  A Shaman from the Elk Uthgardt Tribe.  She too had been shunned by her tribe.  Born with magic in her, she should have been her tribe's Shaman.  But she had no control over it.  Wildly flaring out from her fire would burn the woods in sphere around her.  She was only trying to start a small fire for the night.  It's ok, mother put it out.  Mother was able to help tame her power and get it in control.  Eventually Kelga felt confident enough to try and rejoin her tribe.  She was successful in this.  But she would return to us every now and again, to train with mother some more.  Or seek her help with something above her skills.  She was there when we buried Mother, but came around much less after.

One day Huginn and I were hunting for dinner in the woods. In the distance we heard something fighting. Just terrible monstrous noises, followed by a man's cries for help. Huginn just looked at me, smiled and ran towards the danger. The fool. Yes, you were a fool. Of course it was brave, still foolish. Anyway, I followed. I always followed. But we got there too late. The beast, or beasts, were gone. Leaving behind the splattered remains of some adventurer. He ran off to track the beast. I looked for the man's money pouch. We may live in the wild, but gold can still be useful when we come across travelers or occasionally go to the local town. I do like the stories the travelers tell of their cities. 

Then a stranger came. An old man from a far-off land, covered in a cloak with strange symbols, and a book. We never had any books. But he promised me his book could help me be better than Huginn now, and forever. I just couldn't say no. Greedily said yes without hesitation. He gave me a ring, to give my brother. Said it would make him smarter. I didn't want that, but he promised everything would be as he said. So, I gave it to him. 

Huginn said he felt smarter, and that now he would always be one step ahead of his little brother. The prick. 

Another day while out hunting, we heard those same horrible screams and growls coming from far off in the woods. Huginn looked me in the eye, smiled with delight, and ran in its direction. I wasn't fast enough. Lost sight of him, heard their meeting as Huginn announced himself with a brave roar...only to be followed with a wet guttural gurgling cry of pain, then silence. I didn't even hear the creature leave. But it was gone when I arrived. All that was there was my brother. Torn in two. 

After standing over what was left of his torso for what felt like a day, I howled with heartache I didn't know could exist. I had almost hated him most of our lives, but I absolutely loved him even more. He may have been better than I, but we were a force to be reckoned with, together. Now it was just me, alone. Mother having died years before. I crashed to my knees in crippling sadness. 


My eyes scanning his face, his chest. The markings of our kind streak across only the left half of him. Different as we were, I could never deny that looking at him was like looking into a calm river. For I have the exact same markings, reversed on my right side. The vision of what was essentially me, the best of me, lying there, guts spilled out across the forest floor. There, in the blood and gore was a small glint. The ring I gave him was still on his finger. 

At that exact moment I heard a voice come to my mind. "Take it." It whispered. It said again with more force, "Take it!" Sliding the ring off his bloody finger, and down my own. From his left hand to mine. His blood left wet lines down my finger. "Yes, it's going to work." The voice scratched again, vaguely familiar. 

I lay down by my brother, out of pure mental exhaustion, I slept next to him for the last time. Or so I thought. For when I awoke the ring had linked itself to me. And from within the depths of my own hollow thick skull came the voice of Huginn. "What have you done?" I couldn't answer, I didn't know. 

"What have I done?" Repeating the question out loud as Huginn did in my head. 

"I can tell you." Turning to where the words came from, the first ones not coming from in or out of my own head. I saw the cloaked man. He stood there smiling, as though the sight of my dead and destroyed brother's corpse had just given him a king's ransom in gold. Neither Huginn nor I knew how he had done this, nor did we care. Together we reached for Huginn’s greataxe and swung at the man. He gasped as his eyes widened, and blood slowly dripped from his smiling vile mouth. 

"It worked" were the last words he spoke, as his body fell in two, much like Huginn's. And there standing next to his torn body, was Huginn. Dark grey in color and sort of waving like a distant sight on a hot day. I could see through him. 

Huginn turned to look at me over his shoulder. I was still sitting on the ground, next to his body. I hadn't moved. 

"Get up.  We have work to do."

Over the following months I traveled the lands looking for anything the old, cloaked man was connected to.  Never found a damn thing though.  I was never that good of a hunter, Huginn did all that stuff.  I still needed to eat.  I tried normal work but, I’m not cut out for that shit.  

Then one day in a local town I saw some tougher looking people collecting money from the head of the town.  And all they brought were some dead Kobolds.  Confused, I asked a nearby local who would pay for dead Kobolds?  That’s when I learned about adventurers, heroes, and missions.  Turns out, most towns had a board where people would put their cries for help, and how much they would pay.  That’s it, I’m going to be an adventurer…  We, we are going to be adventurers.  


All though I hadn’t seen that shadow of Huginn again after the day of his death, he never stopped squawking in my head.  Always with an opinion about what I was doing and how I was doing it wrong.  It’s hard to miss the dead when they stay in your head.

Mom had tried to teach me to read; it never really worked out very well.  I just couldn’t make all those squiggles mean anything in my head.  But the other residence of my head could.  If I see it, so does he.  So now it looks like I’m smart enough to read.  What people don’t understand is, it’s just Huginn telling me what I’m looking at.  He definitely took advantage of it a couple times.  Said it was to teach me a lesson about being lazy.  

I don’t see how making me take work to babysit some old crazy lady’s tulip garden taught me anything.  Or when he said it was to get rid of a wyvern terrorizing the town.  But it turned out to be a fully grown dragon.  He says he read it wrong.  But he always laughs when he says it.

Taking these jobs paid for my food.  I was still good at sleeping outside in the woods, so never paid for a room.  Not many people will try to rob a sleeping Goliath.  

In one of the larger cities, I kept seeing this one dwarf at the job boards at the same time I was.  He’d end up taking the same job I did.  Annoying little hairy bastard.  I don’t want or need his help.  But the people always ended up splitting the payment between both of us.  He always looked pissed off about it too.  This continued for a few weeks until I couldn’t take it anymore, and I pushed him away from the board when he approached.

This turned into a big fight.  For a little guy, he packs a heck of wallop.  I don’t know how he even lifts that maul of his.  But he swings it hard.  We did some serious damage to ourselves, and the entire block as well.  There was no winner, anyone watching will tell you that.  But Huginn and he swear the Dwarf won.  They’re both jerks.  

Neither of us had any money to cover the damage and ended up behind bars for the destruction we caused.  I could have left that prison anytime I wanted to.  The bars were not strong.  But Huginn kept me straight.  It was stupidity that landed me here, how would more get me out?  I had no idea what he was talking about.  But to shut him I stayed put.  

The Dwarf never spoke to me.  Spent days next to each other in separate cells, but he just would not speak to me.  I even tried pissing him off to no avail.  He just ignored me.  Later on, he confessed to me that he wasn’t mad.  Just enjoying the free room and food.  Times had been hard on him too.

While we waited for time served, the town was attacked by bandits.  Huginn said now was the time to act.  He told me what to say, and I did so.  This happens far more than I’d like to admit.  He also tells me when to keep my mouth shut.  Now was the time to talk.  He had me say a lot that I can’t remember.  But what I do know is, I promised to fight off these attackers.  The jailer seemed unsure but had no backbone of his own, so he let me out.  Before running out at full speed, as Huginn told me to, I rubbed my chin.  It was still sore from when the Dwarf clocked me days before.  

Ignoring Huginn’s demands to “GET TO WORK”, I motioned for the jailer to let out the Dwarf too.  He never spoke Common.  At that time, I didn’t know, but he only spoke Dwarven.  He yelled at me and the jailer at first.  While his cell was being unlocked, I grabbed Huginn’s greataxe and his maul.  He didn’t want to leave, not with me.  Shoved his maul in his chest and nodded towards the screams outside.  

“Get up, we have work to do”.  He looked me in the eyes through his own furled brow.  I didn’t know if he understood me at first.  Grabbing his maul and nodding his head, we ran together out of the jail and went to work.

Afterwards, the mayor thanked us for the help.  But, after looking at the destruction we left in the process, they told us to leave and never come back.  He and I traveled to the next town together.  Neither of us ever said a word.  We didn’t even look at each other.  After arriving in the next town and finding the jobs board, we both stood in front of it.  We found the same types of jobs we had been doing alone and reached for the same one.  Almost mad at each other, ready to fight over the job, Huginn made a suggestion.  So, I backed off from our stare down, turned towards the board and found a job that paid 3 times as much as the other.  

I looked at the Dwarf and showed him the job, pointing at the pay, then at him, and finally me.  We could do bigger jobs if we worked together.  This continued for some months.  Us working together and not talking.  Till one day while camping in the woods, he started talking.  It was all in Dwarven, so I had no idea what he was saying.  But he looked very serious, sad even.  He had something he needed to get off his chest.  And why not confess your sins to someone that can’t understand you.

After that, he started teaching me some of his language.  I can speak a little of it today because of him.  Not a lot, but enough to get by.  I was hoping my lessons could continue, then I’d be the first of my brother and I to learn a second language.  He likes to say that I was only ever learning anything because he was now my brain.  But that’s now how this works… right?

We had spent more time in a bigger city than intended.  Making and spending a lot of money there.  We even started using the inns and got us a room, with BEDS!!  Those things are nicer than I gave them credit for.  Small though.  Apparently, we stayed long enough in one place for his past to catch up with him.  The innkeeper got his attention and handed him a letter.  Immediately, he ran back to our room and got his stuff together.  I tried to follow him, but he put his hand up and shook his head. About to walk away, he looked at my axe.  He had seen me look at his maul many times.  I did like the way it smashed over the axe cutting.  It made a cooler mess.  He grabbed my axe, shoved his maul in my chest, and walked away.  Never saw him again.  Never even learned his name.

Huginn complained about me letting this little man take his axe but, I really like the maul.  It'll be fine brother.  Some of this life has to be mine after all.  I like this better, deal with it.

Soon after, I found myself in the south of the Sword Coast.  I was camping in the woods.  After the Dwarf left, I liked sleeping outside again.  Took less jobs and hunted for my own food.  Found comfort in solitude, almost.  Huginn would complain a lot.  I wasn’t doing enough.  I needed to go and help people.  Stop evil.  And make things right.  I think to myself, “It will never happen.  Nothing I do will ever be enough for him”.  

“So, you will do it, for the rest of your miserable, lazy life!”

I forgot he could hear my thoughts.  This sucks.

A short time later, in the middle of the night, I was jumped by people unknown.  They knocked the lights outta me.  When I woke, I was in a cage.  There were others caged with me.  I had no idea where I was, or who brought me here.  How long was I out?  WHY DO I HAVE SCALES ON MY BACK!?!  I gotta get outta here.  There was ever only one guard at a time.  Just some guy standing in these black and purple robes.  They don’t look tough, but I’ve seen some little guys toss around fire from their fingertips.  He had keys though.

One night, was it night?  I don’t know, it was always dark and dank in this place.  Anyway, the guards just changed shifts.  Something was different, weird even.  I hadn’t noticed, neither did Huginn, but I could understand them.  Which is weird because, up until now I thought they were speaking in Common.  But no, they sounded like Dragons.  Do I know another language?  But how?  

Anyway, I can’t focus on this now.  Because I saw them hand of keys.  Never noticed that before.  It’s only been a couple days since I woke up.  But I’m not usually very obs, obsvernt… good at noticing things.  I wanted them, needed them to get out.  How was I going to get them.  I’m sure I could knock this guy out with one punch.  As I thought that, I swung at the open air in my cell as hard as I could.  When I did, that shadow of Huginn was suddenly in front of the guard.  And he punched him in the face the same way I did the air!?  This is amazing.  I was right, the guy was out cold.  No one seemed to notice.  

Huginn didn’t disappear.  But he just stood there.  I said out loud, “Get the damn keys brother!”.  

“Shut you mouth idiot.  That isn’t me.  I don’t know what it is, but it’s not me.  I’m still in your head.”

Well, that’s freaking weird.  This is the first time it’s happened since… how would I know how this works?  So, in my head, I again said, “Well, grab the keys.  Get us outta here.”  I could feel Huginn struggling in my head.  “I can’t.” Said Huginn, “I don’t control it.”  After a moment I punched the air again.  It did the same.  So, I control it.  But not in every way.  After trying to get it to pick up the keys, I realized it would not do as I did.  Only when I attacked.  So, I started trying to HIT the keys in my direction.

Fuck that took a long time.  But I finally got it to my cell and through the bars.  Once out, Huginn suggested freeing others that were also prisoners here.  Good idea, it will cause more confusion, I thought.  “And it’s the right thing to do”.  Yeah yeah, sure sure.  The right thing to do.  He felt me roll my eyes at him.

On the way out, there was one separate cell from everyone else.  It had the tiniest window on its door.  When I looked in, I saw this short haired Elvish woman.  But almost half her body looked like a Dragon.  Feeling the scales on my own back, I felt for her.  Huginn said that she looks too far gone, it’s better to leave her.  She might turn on us.  

As I turned to walk away, she said, “WAIT!  Release me, please.  I must find my sister.  She needs me.”  I felt sorry for her.  So did Huginn.  Against his better judgment, we set her free.  She told me her name; I don’t remember it now.  She said that we were being held by the Cult of the Dragon.  That they were experimenting on us.  Which is why we both now have Dragon scales.  Well, I had scales.  She had claws, and an eye too.  Gross.  Both her and Huginn agreed.  We need to find the rest of this Cult and stop them.  For they are truly evil in doing such things.  Our path led us to a small town called Greenest.

traits.personalityTraits:
Crowded spaces make me uncomfortable. I’d much rather be in an open field than a bustling tavern.
What I lack in stature compared to giants, I make up for with sheer spite.
traits.ideals: Doing the good with his life that his deceased brother no longer can.
traits.bonds:
There is no one left alive to care about.  But he is beholden to the life of his deceased brother.  And he misses his mother.  

The mountains and forests are his home.  All of them.  No specific place holds sway for him.  He, his mom, and brother all lived like hermits in nature.   And didn't always stay in one place.

The ring.  He knows he wears it, but he can't see it.
traits.flaws:
Muninn is not very smart.  But for some reason he comes up with moments of wisdom and clarity that just don't make sense to have come from him.

He isn't behaving very lazy right now.  But he wants to be.  He just wants to lounge life away and be left alone.  Nothing sounds better than an undisturbed forest.  He doesn't necessarily dislike his laziness.  But he feels the shame of his brother and mother whenever he is.

definition.name: Hat of Disguise
definition.description: While wearing this hat, you can cast the Disguise Self spell. The spell ends if the hat is removed.

definition.name: Javelin of Lightning
definition.description:
This javelin is a magic weapon. When you hurl it and speak its command word, it transforms into a bolt of lightning, forming a line 5 feet wide that extends out from you to a target within 120 feet. Each creature in the line excluding you and the target must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4d6 lightning damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one. The lightning bolt turns back into a javelin when it reaches the target. Make a ranged weapon attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes damage from the javelin plus 4d6 lightning damage.

The javelin's property can't be used again until the next dawn. In the meantime, the javelin can still be used as a magic weapon.

grantedModifiers.restriction: On Hit or DC 13 Dexterity Save for Half Damage

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack. If the weapon is a Melee weapon, use the same ability modifier for the attack and damage rolls that you use for a melee attack with that weapon.

properties.name: Slow
properties.description: If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to it, you can reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. If the creature is hit more than once by weapons that have this property, the Speed reduction doesn't exceed 10 feet.

definition.name: Ring of Mind Shielding
definition.description:
While wearing this ring, you are immune to magic that allows other creatures to read your thoughts, determine whether you are lying, know your alignment, or know your creature type. Creatures can telepathically communicate with you only if you allow it.

You can use an action to cause the ring to become invisible until you use another action to make it visible, until you remove the ring, or until you die.

If you die while wearing the ring, your soul enters it, unless it already houses a soul. You can remain in the ring or depart for the afterlife. As long as your soul is in the ring, you can telepathically communicate with any creature wearing it. A wearer can't prevent this telepathic communication.

definition.name: Ring of Protection
definition.description: You gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class and saving throws while wearing this ring.

definition.name: Adamantine Half Plate
definition.description: This suit of armor is reinforced with adamantine, one of the hardest substances in existence. While you’re wearing it, any Critical Hit against you becomes a normal hit.

definition.name: Ring of Lightning Resistance
definition.description: You have resistance to lightning damage while wearing this citrine ring.

definition.name: Hazirawn
definition.description:
A sentient (neutral evil) greatsword, Hazirawn is capable of speech in Common and Netherese. Even if you aren’t attuned to the sword, you gain a +1 bonus on attack rolls and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. If you aren’t attuned to Hazirawn, you deal an extra 1d6 necrotic damage when you hit with it.

Increased Potency. While you are attuned to this weapon, its bonus on attack rolls and damage rolls increases to +2, and a hit deals an extra 2d6 necrotic damage (instead of 1d6).

Spells. Hazirawn has 4 charges to cast spells. As long as the sword is attuned to you and you are holding it in your hand, you can use an action to expend the required number of charges to cast one of the following spells from the sword: detect magic (1 charge), detect evil and good (1 charge), or detect thoughts (2 charges). Each night at midnight, Hazirawn regains 1d4 expended charges.

Wounding. While you are attuned to the weapon, any creature that you hit with Hazirawn can’t regain hit points for 1 minute. The target can make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending this effect early on itself on a success.

properties.name: Heavy
properties.description: You have [rules]Disadvantage[/rules] on attack rolls with a Heavy weapon if it’s a Melee weapon and your Strength score isn’t at least 13 or if it’s a Ranged weapon and your Dexterity score isn’t at least 13.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: A Two-Handed weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

properties.name: Graze
properties.description: If your attack roll with this weapon misses a creature, you can deal damage to that creature equal to the ability modifier you used to make the attack roll. This damage is the same type dealt by the weapon, and the damage can be increased only by increasing the ability modifier.

limitedUse.resetTypeDescription: Each night at midnight, Hazirawn regains 1d4 expended charges.

definition.name: Scaled Ornament (Wakened)
definition.description:
This ornament can be jewelry, a cloak, or another wearable accessory. It appears to be fashioned from a dragon’s scale, tooth, or claw, or it incorporates images in those shapes.

Slumbering (Uncommon). You have advantage on saving throws you make to avoid being charmed or frightened or to end those conditions on you.

Stirring (Rare). You gain a +1 bonus to AC, and you can’t be charmed or frightened. Moreover, each creature of your choice within 30 feet of you has advantage on saving throws it makes to avoid being charmed or frightened or to end those conditions on itself.

Wakened (Very Rare). The Wakened ornament has the Stirring property. In addition, when you would take damage of the type dealt by the breath of the dragon in whose hoard the ornament became Wakened, you can use your reaction to take no damage instead, and you regain hit points equal to the damage you would have taken. Once this property is used, it can’t be used again until the next dawn.

definition.name: Handaxe
definition.description:
Proficiency with a Handaxe allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Vex. If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to the creature, you have Advantage on your next attack roll against that creature before the end of your next turn.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: When you take the [action]Attack[/action] action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon, you can make one extra attack as a Bonus Action later on the same turn. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon, and you don’t add your ability modifier to the extra attack’s damage unless that modifier is negative. For example, you can attack with a [items]Shortsword[/items] in one hand and a [items]Dagger[/items] in the other using the [action]Attack[/action] action and a Bonus Action, but you don’t add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the Bonus Action unless that modifier is negative.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack. If the weapon is a Melee weapon, use the same ability modifier for the attack and damage rolls that you use for a melee attack with that weapon.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description:
A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

definition.name: Bedroll
definition.description: You never know where you’re going to sleep, and a bedroll helps you get better sleep in a hayloft or on the cold ground. A bedroll consists of bedding and a blanket thin enough to be rolled up and tied. In an emergency, it can double as a stretcher.

definition.name: Chest
definition.description: A chest can hold 12 cubic feet/ 300 pounds of gear.

definition.name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
definition.description: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

definition.name: Mess Kit
definition.description: This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

definition.name: Rations (1 day)
definition.description: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Torch
definition.description: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

definition.name: Block and Tackle
definition.description: A set of pulleys with a cable threaded through them and a hook to attach to objects, a block and tackle allows you to hoist up to four times the weight you can normally lift.

definition.name: Manacles
definition.description: These metal restraints can bind a Small or Medium creature. Escaping the manacles requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. Breaking them requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. Each set of manacles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick the manacles' lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Manacles have 15 hit points.

definition.name: Fighter
definition.description:
A master of martial combat, skilled with a variety of weapons and armor

Hit Die: d10
Primary Ability: Strength or Dexterity
Saves: Strength & Constitution
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) chain mail or (b) leather armor, longbow, and 20 arrows
  • (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons
  • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) two handaxes
  • (a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

classFeatures.name: Fighting Style
classFeatures.description: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeatures.name: Second Wind
classFeatures.description: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

classFeatures.name: Action Surge
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.

classFeatures.name: Martial Archetype
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Choose Champion, Battle Master, or Eldritch Knight, all detailed at the end of the class description. The archetype you choose grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 6th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 11th level, you can attack three times, instead of twice, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you can attack four times, instead of three, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d10 per fighter level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per fighter level after 1st

subclassDefinition.name: Echo Knight
subclassDefinition.description: A mysterious and feared frontline warrior of the Kryn Dynasty, the Echo Knight has mastered the art of using dunamis to summon the fading shades of unrealized timelines to aid them in battle. Surrounded by echoes of their own might, they charge into the fray as a cycling swarm of shadows and strikes.

classFeatures.name: Manifest Echo
classFeatures.description:
3rd-level Echo Knight feature

You can use a bonus action to magically manifest an echo of yourself in an unoccupied space you can see within 15 feet of you. This echo is a magical, translucent, gray image of you that lasts until it is destroyed, until you dismiss it as a bonus action, until you manifest another echo, or until you’re incapacitated.

Your echo has AC 14 + your proficiency bonus, 1 hit point, and immunity to all conditions. If it has to make a saving throw, it uses your saving throw bonus for the roll. It is the same size as you, and it occupies its space. On your turn, you can mentally command the echo to move up to 30 feet in any direction (no action required). If your echo is ever more than 30 feet from you at the end of your turn, it is destroyed.

You can use the echo in the following ways:

  • As a bonus action, you can teleport, magically swapping places with your echo at a cost of 15 feet of your movement, regardless of the distance between the two of you.
  • When you take the Attack action on your turn, any attack you make with that action can originate from your space or the echo’s space. You make this choice for each attack.
  • When a creature that you can see within 5 feet of your echo moves at least 5 feet away from it, you can use your reaction to make an opportunity attack against that creature as if you were in the echo’s space.

classFeatures.name: Unleash Incarnation
classFeatures.description:
3rd-level Echo Knight feature

You can heighten your echo’s fury. Whenever you take the Attack action, you can make one additional melee attack from the echo’s position.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Echo Avatar
classFeatures.description:
7th-level Echo Knight feature

You can temporarily transfer your consciousness to your echo. As an action, you can see through your echo’s eyes and hear through its ears. During this time, you are deafened and blinded. You can sustain this effect for up to 10 minutes, and you can end it at any time (requires no action). While your echo is being used in this way, it can be up to 1,000 feet away from you without being destroyed.

classFeatures.name: Shadow Martyr
classFeatures.description:
10th-level Echo Knight feature

You can make your echo throw itself in front of an attack directed at another creature that you can see. Before the attack roll is made, you can use your reaction to teleport the echo to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the targeted creature. The attack roll that triggered the reaction is instead made against your echo.

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

classFeatures.name: Reclaim Potential
classFeatures.description:
15th-level Echo Knight feature

You’ve learned to absorb the fleeting magic of your echo. When an echo of yours is destroyed by taking damage, you can gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 2d6 + your Constitution modifier, provided you don’t already have temporary hit points.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Legion of One
classFeatures.description:
18th-level Echo Knight feature

You can use a bonus action to create two echoes with your Manifest Echo feature, and these echoes can coexist. If you try to create a third echo, the previous two echoes are destroyed. Anything you can do from one echo’s position can be done from the other’s instead.

In addition, when you roll initiative and have no uses of your Unleash Incarnation feature left, you regain one use of that feature.

definition.name: Reclaim Potential
definition.description:
15th-level Echo Knight feature

You’ve learned to absorb the fleeting magic of your echo. When an echo of yours is destroyed by taking damage, you can gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 2d6 + your Constitution modifier, provided you don’t already have temporary hit points.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
definition.snippet:
You’ve learned to absorb the fleeting magic of your echo. When an echo of yours is destroyed by taking damage, you can gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 2d6 + {{modifier:con#unsigned}}, provided you don’t already have temporary hit points.

You can use this feature {{modifier:con@min:1#unsigned}} time(s). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

definition.name: Legion of One
definition.description:
18th-level Echo Knight feature

You can use a bonus action to create two echoes with your Manifest Echo feature, and these echoes can coexist. If you try to create a third echo, the previous two echoes are destroyed. Anything you can do from one echo’s position can be done from the other’s instead.

In addition, when you roll initiative and have no uses of your Unleash Incarnation feature left, you regain one use of that feature.
definition.snippet:
You can use a bonus action to create two echoes with your Manifest Echo feature, and these echoes can coexist. If you try to create a third echo, the previous two echoes are destroyed. Anything you can do from one echo’s position can be done from the other’s instead.

In addition, when you roll initiative and have no uses of your Unleash Incarnation feature left, you regain one use of that feature.

definition.name: Fighting Style
definition.description: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
definition.snippet: You adopt a fighting style specialty.

definition.name: Second Wind
definition.description: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.
definition.snippet: Once per short rest, you can use a bonus action to regain 1d10 + {{classlevel}} HP.

definition.name: Action Surge
definition.description:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.
definition.snippet: You can take one additional action on your turn. This can be used {{scalevalue}} times per short rest.

definition.name: Martial Archetype
definition.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Choose Champion, Battle Master, or Eldritch Knight, all detailed at the end of the class description. The archetype you choose grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.
definition.snippet: You can attack twice whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription:
This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

definition.name: Indomitable
definition.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.
definition.snippet: You can reroll a saving throw that you fail - you must use the new roll. You can use this {{scalevalue}} times per long rest.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 6th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 11th level, you can attack three times, instead of twice, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to four when you reach 20th level in this class.
definition.snippet: You can attack three times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription: This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description: At 20th level, you can attack four times, instead of three, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.snippet: You can attack four times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription: This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

definition.name: Proficiencies
definition.description:
Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival
definition.multiClassDescription:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons

definition.name: Hit Points
definition.description:
Hit Dice: 1d10 per fighter level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per fighter level after 1st

definition.name: Equipment
definition.description:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) chain mail or (b) leather armor, longbow, and 20 arrows
  • (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons
  • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) two handaxes
  • (a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

definition.name: Barbarian
definition.description:
A fierce warrior who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: Strength
Saves: Strength & Constitution
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

classFeatures.name: Rage
classFeatures.description:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.

classFeatures.name: Unarmored Defense
classFeatures.description: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Reckless Attack
classFeatures.description: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

classFeatures.name: Danger Sense
classFeatures.description:
At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.

classFeatures.name: Primal Path
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the nature of your rage. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.description:

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Fast Movement
classFeatures.description: Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.

classFeatures.name: Feral Instinct
classFeatures.description:
By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
At 13th level, you can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description: At 17th level, you can roll three additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

classFeatures.name: Relentless Rage
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

classFeatures.name: Persistent Rage
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall unconscious or if you choose to end it.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable Might
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a Strength check is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeatures.name: Primal Champion
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from Animal Handling, Athletics, Intimidation, Nature, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d12 per barbarian level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per barbarian level after 1st

subclassDefinition.name: Path of the Giant
subclassDefinition.description: Barbarians who walk the Path of the Giant draw strength from the same primal forces as giants. As they rage, these barbarians surge with elemental power and grow in size, taking on forms that evoke the glory of giants. Some barbarians look like oversized versions of themselves, perhaps with a hint of elemental energy flaring in their eyes and around their weapons. Others transform more dramatically, taking on the appearance of an actual giant or a form similar to an Elemental, wreathed in fire, frost, or lightning.

classFeatures.name: Giant’s Power
classFeatures.description:
3rd-Level Path of the Giant Feature

When you choose this path, you learn to speak, read, and write Giant or one other language of your choice if you already know Giant. Additionally, you learn a cantrip of your choice: either druidcraft or thaumaturgy. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

classFeatures.name: Giant’s Havoc
classFeatures.description:
3rd-Level Path of the Giant Feature

Your rages pull strength from the primal might of giants, transforming you into a hulking force of destruction. While raging, you gain the following benefits:

Crushing Throw. When you make a successful ranged attack with a thrown weapon using Strength, you can add your Rage Damage bonus to the attack’s damage roll.

Giant Stature. Your reach increases by 5 feet, and if you are smaller than Large, you become Large, along with anything you are wearing. If there isn’t enough room for you to increase your size, your size doesn’t change.

classFeatures.name: Elemental Cleaver
classFeatures.description:
6th-Level Path of the Giant Feature

Your bond with the elemental might of giants grows, and you learn to infuse weapons with primordial energy.

When you enter your rage, you can choose one weapon that you are holding and infuse it with one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, thunder, or lightning. While you wield the infused weapon during your rage, the weapon’s damage type changes to the chosen type, it deals an extra 1d6 damage of the chosen type when it hits, and it gains the thrown property, with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet. If you throw the weapon, it reappears in your hand the instant after it hits or misses a target. The infused weapon’s benefits are suppressed while a creature other than you wields it.

While raging and holding the infused weapon, you can use a bonus action to change the infused weapon’s current damage type to another one from the damage type options above.

classFeatures.name: Mighty Impel
classFeatures.description:
10th-Level Path of the Giant Feature

Your connection to giant strength allows you to hurl both allies and enemies on the battlefield. As a bonus action while raging, you can choose one Medium or smaller creature within your reach and move it to an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of yourself. An unwilling creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) to avoid the effect.

If, at the end of this movement, the thrown creature isn’t on a surface or liquid that can support it, the creature falls, taking damage as normal and landing prone.

classFeatures.name: Demiurgic Colossus
classFeatures.description:
14th-Level Path of the Giant Feature

The primordial power of your rage intensifies. When you rage, your reach increases by 10 feet, your size can increase to Large or Huge (your choice), and you can use your Mighty Impel to move creatures that are Large or smaller.

In addition, the extra damage dealt by your Elemental Cleaver feature increases to 2d6.

  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.
